questions.text: A 25-year-old male with thalassemia major presents to the clinic with increased fatigue, joint pain, and symptoms of hyperglycemia. On examination, he has a discoloration of the skin as shown. His medical history includes multiple blood transfusions over the years. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in managing his condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule a follow-up for skin assessment

questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Cause
  • Primarily linked to thalassemia major
  • Regular blood transfusions cause pancreatic iron overload, impairing insulin secretion

Symptoms
  • Typical diabetes symptoms (hyperglycemia)
  • Joint pain and fatigue
  • Skin changes less prominent in darker complexions

Diagnosis
  • Often after diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Elevated blood glucose levels and serum ferritin indicating iron overload

Management

Details

Insulin Therapy

Many patients require insulin for effective blood glucose management.

Iron Chelation Therapy

Helps reduce body iron levels, mitigating complications from iron overload.

Regular Monitoring

Continuous assessment of blood glucose and serum ferritin is crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman experiences severe postpartum hemorrhage during delivery, requiring a blood transfusion. Two weeks later, she reports fatigue, weight loss, and inability to breastfeed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Sheehan Syndrome
Pathology

Decrease in anterior pituitary hormones due to ischemic damage of anterior pituitary

Initial Symptoms

Classic early sign is failed lactation following delivery

Varied Symptoms

Based on the severity of pituitary damage

  • Severe Hypopituitarism:
    • Early symptoms :lethargy, anorexia, and weight loss soon after delivery.
    • Delayed Symptoms: Secondary amenorrhea, loss of sexual hair, and fatigue may develop weeks to months later.
 
  • Growth Hormone (GH) deficiency: Often the first hormone to be lost, leading to Hypoglycemia, muscle weakness, and mood swings.
 
  • Signs of Premature aging: Wrinkling of face
 
  • ACTH Deficiency: Can cause postural hypotension & worsen hypoglycemia.
 
  • Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) Deficiency: Results in secondary hypothyroidism . Unlike primary hypothyroidism, frank myxoedema is rare.
 
  • Approximately ⅓ rd may present with hyponatremia, while Central diabetes insipidus is rarely observed.

 

Sheehan syndrome

Simmonds disease

Cause

Ischemic damage to the anterior pituitary due to acute infarction

Gradual degeneration or destruction of the pituitary due to hypertension / SCD

Symptoms

Failure to lactate, lethargy, anorexia, and weight loss shortly after delivery

 

Secondary amenorrhea, loss of sexual hair, fatigue, and wrinkling of the face (premature ageing) can occur as delayed symptoms.

Gradual weakness, weight loss, and signs of pituitary hormone deficiency

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with symptoms suggestive of acromegaly, including enlarged hands and facial changes. To confirm the diagnosis, which of the following tests is most appropriate to demonstrate the presence of the condition?

A 45-year-old man presents with enlarged hands, facial changes, and spacing between his lower teeth. Lab results show elevated growth hormone and IGF-1 levels. What is the most common cause of his condition?
questions.explanation:
Acromegaly

Causes
  • GH-secreting pituitary adenomas (>1cm-macroadenoma) (Most Common)
  • Mixed mammosomatotroph tumors (25%) (Option A ruled out)
  • Acidophilic stem cell adenomas, which also secrete prolactin (PRL), lead to symptoms such as hypogonadism and galactorrhea.
  • Carcinoid tumor: Excess GNRH production (Option D ruled out)
  • Tumors in the pancreas, ovaries, and lungs: Ectopic GH secretion (Option C ruled out)

Clinical features
  • Acral bony overgrowth
    • Frontal bossing
    • Enlarged hands and feet
    • Mandibular enlargement with prognathism
    • Widened spaces between lower incisor teeth.
  • Soft tissue swelling:
    • Increased heel pad thickness (>25mm)
    • Larger shoe and glove sizes
    • Ring tightening
    • Coarse facial features
    • Macroglossia
  • Visceromegaly: particularly cardiomegaly and thyroid enlargement
  • Other symptoms
    • Hyperhidrosis and oily skin
    • Deep voice,
    • Arthropathy, kyphosis and carpal tunnel syndrome,
    • Muscle weakness and atrophy
    • Acanthosis nigricans and skin tags.

Complications
  • Cardiomyopathy: Characterized by arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy, decreased diastolic function, and hypertension.
  • Upper airway obstruction: Sleep apnea, caused by laryngeal obstruction and central sleep dysfunction, affects over 60% of patients.
  • Diabetes mellitus: Approximately 25% of patients develop diabetes, as GH antagonizes insulin action.
  • Hypertension
  • Arthritis
  • Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Colon polyps and malignancy, with up to one-third of patients at risk
  • Mass effect by the adenoma, including visual disturbances.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a history of weight loss, palpitations, and heat intolerance. On examination, she has a diffuse goitre, Ophthalmopathy and fine tremors in her outstretched hands. Her thyroid function tests show: TSH: < 0.01 mIU/L (normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L) Free T4: 35 pmol/L (normal range: 10-20 pmol/L) Free T3: 12 pmol/L (normal range: 3.5-6.5 pmol/L) Which of the following is the most likely cause of her hyperthyroidism?
questions.explanation:
Cause

Key Features for identification

Primary Hyperthyroidism (pathology within the thyroid gland)

Graves' disease

Diffuse goitre, ophthalmopathy, TSH receptor antibodies (LATS- long-acting thyroid stimulating antibodies)

Toxic multinodular goiter

Multiple autonomous nodules, older patients

Toxic adenoma

Single autonomous nodule

Subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain thyroiditis)

Painful thyroid, recent viral illness, transient

Silent thyroiditis (Painless lymphocytic thyroiditis)

Painless, often postpartum, transient

Iodine-induced thyrotoxicosis

History of iodine exposure (e.g., contrast, amiodarone)

Drug-induced (e.g., amiodarone)

History of relevant medication use

Secondary Hyperthyroidism

TSH-secreting pituitary adenoma

Inappropriate TSH secretion, other pituitary hormones may be affected

hCG-mediated hyperthyroidism

Pregnancy, gestational trophoblastic disease

(Alpha subunit of hCG is similar in structure to TSH)

Thyroid hormone resistance (rare)

Genetic disorder, reduced sensitivity of the body to thyroid hormone.

Ectopic Hyperthyroidism

Struma ovarii

Ovarian teratoma with functional thyroid tissue

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of multinodular goitre undergoes a CT angiogram with iodinated contrast for suspected pulmonary embolism. Two weeks later, she presents with palpitations, heat intolerance, and weight loss. Her thyroid function tests show suppressed TSH and elevated T3 and T4. Which of the following best explains this patient's current condition?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Wolff-Chaikoff Effect

Jod-Basedow Effect

Definition

Temporary inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis in response to high iodine exposure

Iodine-induced hyperthyroidism

Mechanism

High iodine levels inhibit thyroid peroxidase, reducing T3 and T4 production

Excess iodine stimulates autonomous thyroid hormone production in susceptible individuals

Duration

Temporary (usually resolves in 1-2 weeks)

Can persist until treated

Thyroid Function Tests

Initially decreased T3 and T4, increased TSH

Increased T3 and T4, decreased TSH

At-risk Population

Normal thyroid glands

Pre-existing thyroid disease (e.g., multinodular goiter, Graves' disease)

Clinical Presentation

Usually asymptomatic or mild hypothyroid symptoms

Symptoms of hyperthyroidism (e.g., palpitations, heat intolerance, weight loss)

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with hyperthermia, tachycardia, and altered mental status following an abrupt discontinuation of her antithyroid medication. Upon examination, she is diaphoretic, has a goitre, and exhibits hand tremors. Which of the following is the DOC for managing her condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Administer a large dose of Propylthiouracil

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer a large dose of Propylthiouracil
questions.explanation:
Thyroid Storm

Clinical Features
  • Fever with diaphoresis.
  • Cardiovascular Involvement: Tachycardia (>140 bpm), heart failure, arrhythmias, hypotension, and risk of cardiac arrest.
  • CNS Manifestations: Agitation, delirium, anxiety, psychosis, or coma.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, intestinal obstruction, and acute hepatic failure.

Management
  • Initial Supportive Measures: IV fluids, oxygen, cooling blankets, and acetaminophen.
  • Beta-blocker Therapy: Start with propranolol immediately (40-80 mg every 4-6 hours) to control adrenergic tone.
  • DOC: Administer propylthiouracil (500-1000 mg loading, then 250 mg every 4 hours) or methimazole (20 mg every 4-6 hours). 
  • Iodine Solution: Give SSKI (5 drops every 6 hours) after thionamide to reduce the release of thyroid hormone
  • Glucocorticoids: Hydrocortisone (100 mg IV every 8 hours) or dexamethasone (2 mg every 6 hours).
  • Cholestyramine (Bile acid sequestrant): 4 grams orally 4 times daily for severe cases to reduce enterohepatic recycling of thyroid hormone.
  • Surgery: Thyroidectomy for patients with contraindications to thionamides after pre-treatment.
  • Definitive Treatment: Recommend radioiodine therapy or surgery for hyperthyroidism once stabilised.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes presents for a routine eye examination. On examination, she is found to have microaneurysms, retinal haemorrhages, and cotton wool spots. What is the most effective management option for her symptomatic foveal oedema?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Feature

Description

Detection

Capillary occlusion visible only on retinal angiography.

Microaneurysms

Form on occluded capillaries, leaking fluid and blood.

Oedema and Haemorrhages

Caused by leakage; lipids precipitate to form exudate.

Capillary Changes

Occluded capillaries turn white and disappear.

Retinal Ischaemia

Larger patches form as more capillaries occlude.

New Vessels

Grow at the border of diseased and non-diseased retina due to increased VEGF from ischaemia.

Intraretinal Microvascular Abnormalities (IRMAs)

Form from partially perfused capillaries.

Venous Beading

Develops in retinal veins (multiple diffuse swellings).

Flame Haemorrhages

Horizontal streaky haemorrhages in the retinal nerve-fibre layer.

Cotton Wool Spots

Located in the nerve-fibre layer, usually found nasal to the optic disc.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes presents for routine evaluation. He has poorly controlled blood sugar levels, and reports increased urination. Urinalysis reveals microalbuminuria. Which of the following management strategies is most crucial in slowing the progression of diabetic nephropathy in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Strict glycemic control using insulin therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Aggressive blood pressure control using ACE inhibitors

options.label: C
options.text: Dietary modification to reduce protein intake

options.label: D
options.text: Initiation of statin therapy regardless of cholesterol levels

questions.correct_answer: B. Aggressive blood pressure control using ACE inhibitors
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Definition

Serious complication of type 1 and type 2 diabetes; leads to end-stage renal failure in 20-50% of patients.

Pathology

Damage to small blood vessels (diabetic microangiopathy); characterized by capillary basement membrane thickening, increased permeability, and matrix accumulation.

Key Factors

Hyperglycemia activates the renin-angiotensin system.

Prolonged hyperglycemia causes inflammation and fibrosis.

Progression

Early hyperfiltration declines over ~10 years; proteinuria develops, reaching nephrotic range by ~14 years.

Risk Factors

Poor glycemic control, long diabetes duration, other microvascular complications, ethnicity (Asians, Pima Indians), pre-existing hypertension, family history.

Diagnosis

Microalbuminuria detected via albumin-to-creatinine ratio; overt nephropathy diagnosed with macroalbuminuria (>300 mg/24 hrs).

Management Goals

Slow kidney damage progression; manage cardiovascular risk.

Management Strategies

Blood pressure control: ACE inhibitors or ARBs.

Glycemic control: strict management.

Cardiovascular risk management: address smoking, hypertension, and consider statin therapy.

Monitoring

Regular monitoring of electrolytes and renal function when using ACE inhibitors/ARBs; alternatives for those intolerant.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a 15-year history of diabetes presents with numbness and tingling in his feet. On examination, he shows diminished vibration sensation in a "glove and stocking" distribution and has absent ankle reflexes. Which of the following features is most characteristic of diabetic neuropathy?

options.label: A
options.text: Distal muscle weakness with atrophy of the interosseous muscles

options.label: B
options.text: Thickening of the Schwann cell basal lamina

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of significant sensory loss in the hands

questions.correct_answer: B. Thickening of the Schwann cell basal lamina
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Prevalence
  • 50–90% of people with diabetes; 15–30% develop painful neuropathy

Pathological Features
  • Axonal degeneration (myelinated/unmyelinated fibers)
  • Thickened Schwann cell basal lamina
  • Patchy demyelination
  • Abnormal intraneural capillaries

Classification
  • Somatic: Symmetrical polyneuropathy (sensory, distal), Asymmetrical polyneuropathy (motor, proximal), Mononeuropathy
  • Visceral: Autonomic dysfunction (various systems)

Common Manifestations
  • Symmetrical Sensory Polyneuropathy: Paresthesia, pain, burning sensations, abnormal gait
  • Asymmetrical Motor Neuropathy: Muscle weakness, pain, weight loss, absent reflexes
  • Autonomic Neuropathy: Affects visceral systems

Gastroparesis Symptoms
  • Chronic nausea, vomiting of undigested food, abdominal pain, early satiety

Management
  • Glycemic control (intensive insulin therapy)
  • Anticonvulsants (gabapentin, pregabalin)
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (amitriptyline, imipramine)
  • Other antidepressants (duloxetine)
  • Topical treatments (capsaicin)
  • Opiates (tramadol, oxycodone)
  • Membrane stabilizers (mexiletine)
  • Antioxidants (alpha-lipoic acid)

Diabetic Foot Complications
  • Risk of ulcers from neuropathy/peripheral vascular disease; management includes preventative care and treatment tailored to ulcers

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with Type 1 diabetes is currently using NPH insulin for his basal needs but struggles with hypoglycemia during the night. After a review of his regimen, the physician suggests switching to a peakless long-acting insulin. Which insulin would be most appropriate for him?
questions.explanation:
Properties of Insulin Preparations

Preparation

Time of Action

Onset, h

Peak, h

Effective Duration, h

Long-acting

Degludec (peakless longest acting)

1-9

-

42

Detemir (peakless insulin)

1-4

-

12-24

Glargine (peakless insulin) (Option B)

2-4

-

20-24

NPH (Intermediate-acting)

2-4

4-10

10-16

Short-acting

Aspart (rapid) (Option C ruled out)

<0.25

0.5-1.5

3-5

Glulisine (rapid) (Option A ruled out)

<0.25

0.5-1.5

3-5

Lispro (rapid)

<0.25

0.5-1.5

3-5

Regular

0.5-1.0

2-3

4-8

Inhaled human insulin (rapid) (Afrezza) (Option D ruled out)

<0.5

1-2

3

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with muscle weakness and frequent headaches. On examination, his blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg, and laboratory tests reveal hypokalemia. Further evaluation shows suppressed plasma renin activity and elevated plasma aldosterone concentration. Which of the following is the most likely clinical feature associated with this condition?

A 52-year-old man presents with symptoms of weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, purple abdominal striae, hyperpigmentation of knuckles, and muscle weakness. Imaging reveals a lung mass. Which of the following is the most likely cause in this patient?

A patient with a history of neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) presents with symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, including frequent episodes of watery diarrhea and flushing. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment to control these symptoms, particularly diarrhea?
questions.explanation:
Carcinoid Syndrome
  • Carcinoid syndrome is caused by hormone secretion (mainly serotonin) from neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).
  • Commonly arises from NETs in the small intestine or appendix.
  • The syndrome typically occurs when the tumor has metastasized to the liver or retroperitoneum, allowing the hormones to enter systemic circulation.
  • Histamine and tachykinins (e.g., substance P) may also contribute to the syndrome.

Common Symptoms
  • Flushing: Sudden onset of an intense red or purplish color, especially on the upper body, neck, and face, often with a sensation of warmth.
  • Diarrhea: Frequent watery stools, often over 10 times/day, significantly impacting daily life.

Less Common Symptoms
  • Wheezing or asthma-like symptoms
  • Impaired cognitive function in advanced cases
  • Pellagra-like skin lesions due to niacin deficiency (from tryptophan being used to produce serotonin instead of niacin).

Management
  • Somatostatin analogues: Mainstay treatment that mimics somatostatin, which inhibits hormone secretion (e.g., serotonin).
    • Most NETs (around 90%) have somatostatin receptors and respond to these analogues.
  • Telotristat ethyl: Blocks serotonin production; used as adjunctive therapy for patients who don't fully respond to somatostatin analogues. (Option B ruled out)
  • Surgery: Considered for localized tumors but often not possible in patients with metastatic disease.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic conditions are associated with pheochromocytomas?
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Pheochromocytomas are rare tumors arising from chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla.
  • The clinical features result from excessive secretion of catecholamines.

Epidemiology
  • Estimated to occur in 2 to 8 of 1 million persons per year.
  • The mean age at diagnosis is 40 years, although the tumours can occur from early childhood until late in life.
  • The classic ‘rule of tens’ is 10% bilateral, 10% extra-adrenal (Paragangliomas), and 10% metastatic. It is not used nowadays.

Etiopathogenesis
  • These tumors can be benign or malignant and are frequently associated with familial syndromes like
    • Neurofibromatosis type 1,
    • multiple endocrine neoplasia type II, and
    • Von-Hippel Lindau disease.
  • Catecholamines are produced in the chromaffin cells starting with the rate-limiting step of tyrosine hydroxylase (TH), regulating the conversion of tyrosine to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).
  • Pheochromocytomas release these catecholamines in various patterns ranging from paroxysmal, continuous, and mixed patterns. Norepinephrine is released continuously and can result in persistent hypertension, while epinephrine is released in a paroxysmal pattern resulting in tachyarrhythmias.
    • Ryanodine-2 receptors (RyR2).
    • Beta-2 adrenoceptors
    • Alpha(1)-adrenoreceptors

Histopathology
  • Histology of the lesion characteristically shows zellballen nests of chromaffin cells with strong positivity to chromogranin, synaptophysin, CD56, and focally to S100.
  • The presence of chromaffin cells in the extra-adrenal tissue is the only pathognomonic characteristic of the malignant form of the entity.

Clinical features
  • Classical triad
    • Episode of palpitation
    • Headache
    • Profuse sweating
  • Dominant sign is Hypertension
  • Tachycardia
  • Anxiety
  • Subcutaneous neurofibromas
  • Cafe-au-lait macules
  • Thyroid mass
  • Axillary freckling
  • Lisch nodules on the iris
  • Retinal angiomas
  • Abdominal mass

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma can be established by biochemical confirmation of hypersecretion of metanephrines and catecholamines.

24-hour urine test

  • Catecholamines
  • Fractionated metanephrines
  • Total metanephrines

Imaging:

  • CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to locate the tumor.
  • 18F-FDG PET scanning is recommended for metastatic disease.
  • MIBG scintigraphy
  • Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • Gallium DOTATATE PET scanning    

Differential Diagnosis
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Renal artery stenosis
  • Hyperaldosteronism
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Postural tachycardia syndrome (POTS)

Treatment
  • The definitive treatment of pheochromocytoma is surgical resection.
  • Preoperative preparation of the patient has to be considered, and blood pressure should be consistently < 160/90 mm Hg.
  • Blood pressure is controlled by alpha-adrenergic blockers(phenoxybenzamine 0.5-4 mg/kg of body weight)
  • Oral Prazosin or IV phentolamine can be used to control paroxysm.

Unilateral Pheochromocytoma:

  • Minimally invasive adrenalectomy: Preferred treatment for most unilateral adrenal pheochromocytomas.
  • Open adrenalectomy

Bilateral pheochromocytomas:

  • Bilateral total adrenalectomy is associated with a lifelong need for steroid replacement with long-term side effects.
  • Bilateral partial or cortical sparing adrenalectomy (open or laparoscopic)

Complications
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Cardiogenic shock
  • Renal Failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Hypertensive retinopathy
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after a sudden onset of fever, vomiting, and irritability. The child’s parents report that he had a productive cough and runny nose for the past few days, which seemed to improve before the acute deterioration. On examination, the child appears lethargic and is febrile (39°C or 102.2°F). There is hypotension (blood pressure 85/50 mmHg), and he is tachycardic (heart rate 120 bpm). Physical examination reveals diffuse petechial rashes on the lower extremities and trunk. Laboratory findings show: WBC count : 18,000/µL (elevated) Blood cultures :  Which laboratory finding is most commonly associated with Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome?

A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents for a routine check-up. He has no symptoms but is concerned about his blood sugar levels. His lab results show: Fasting plasma glucose: 128 mg/dL (7.1 mmol/L) HbA1c: 6.7% What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat fasting plasma glucose for confirmation

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT)

options.label: C
options.text: Start lifestyle modifications and monitor for pre-diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnose diabetes mellitus and initiate treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. Repeat fasting plasma glucose for confirmation
questions.explanation:
Test

Diagnostic Threshold for Diabetes

Random plasma glucose

≥ 200 mg/dL

Fasting plasma glucose

≥ 126 mg/dL

Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT)

≥ 200 mg/dL after 2 hours with 75 g glucose.

OGTT is not necessary if fasting glucose is already in the diabetic range. (Option B ruled out)

Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c)

< 5.7% : Normal

5.7% - 6.5% : Pre-diabetic

> 6.5% : Diabetic

Type

Blood Glucose Range

Impaired fasting glucose

110–125 mg/dL (6.1–6.9 mmol/L) (Option C ruled out)

Impaired glucose tolerance

Fasting < 126 mg/dL + 2-hour OGTT: 140–200 mg/dL (7.8–11.1 mmol/L).

Investigation

Purpose

Islet Autoantibodies

Indicates type 1 diabetes (autoimmune destruction).

C-peptide Measurement

Differentiates type 1 (low C-peptide) vs. severe insulin resistance (high C-peptide).

Urine Protein Testing

Detects microalbuminuria for nephropathy and cardiovascular risk.

Lipid Profile

Identifies dyslipidemia, a common comorbidity in diabetes.

Liver and Thyroid Tests

Detects abnormalities related to diabetes complications.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Random plasma cortisol of >500 nmol/L excludes adrenal insufficiency

options.label: B
options.text: Plasma renin will be high in mineralocorticoid deficiency

options.label: C
options.text: Aldosterone level will be low or in the lower part of the reference range in mineralocorticoid deficiency

questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Investigations Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency) (Option A ruled out). Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency) (Options B & C ruled out). Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative.
  • ↳ Investigations
  • ↳ Investigations
  • ↳ Investigations
  • ↳ Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency) (Option A ruled out). Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency) (Options B & C ruled out). Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative.
  • ↳ Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency) (Option A ruled out). Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency) (Options B & C ruled out). Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative.
  • ↳ Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency) (Option A ruled out).
  • ↳ (Option A ruled out).
  • ↳ Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency
  • ↳ Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency) (Options B & C ruled out).
  • ↳ (Options B & C ruled out).
  • ↳ Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women
  • ↳ Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative.
  • ↳ Management 1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is preferred, and Prednisolone and dexamethasone may also be used. 2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone
  • ↳ Management
  • ↳ Management
  • ↳ Management
  • ↳ 1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is preferred, and Prednisolone and dexamethasone may also be used. 2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone
  • ↳ 1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is preferred, and Prednisolone and dexamethasone may also be used.
  • ↳ 2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone
  • ↳ Addisonian Crisis An Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening medical emergency that occurs when there is a severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone. It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery). Management: IV Hydrocortisone
  • ↳ Addisonian Crisis
  • ↳ Addisonian Crisis
  • ↳ Addisonian Crisis
  • ↳ An Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening medical emergency that occurs when there is a severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone. It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery). Management: IV Hydrocortisone
  • ↳ An Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening medical emergency that occurs when there is a severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone. It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery).
  • ↳ Addisonian crisis
  • ↳ Addison's disease
  • ↳ Management: IV Hydrocortisone
  • ↳ Management: IV Hydrocortisone

Investigations
  • Random plasma cortisol measurement (values >500 nmol/L exclude adrenal insufficiency) (Option A ruled out).
  • Short ACTH stimulation test- if random cortisol levels are between 100-500, 1 microgram ACTH, serum cortisol levels of <500 is considered confirmatory for adrenal insufficiency 
  • Plasma renin and aldosterone (high renin with low/lower part of the reference range aldosterone in mineralocorticoid deficiency) (Options B & C ruled out).
  • Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and androstenedione in women
  • Adrenal autoantibodies for autoimmune causes; imaging (CT/MRI) if antibodies are negative.

Management

1. Glucocorticoid Replacement: Oral hydrocortisone is preferred, and Prednisolone and dexamethasone may also be used.

2. Mineralocorticoid Replacement: Fludrocortisone

Addisonian Crisis

An Addisonian crisis is a life-threatening medical emergency that occurs when there is a severe deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone. It is most commonly seen in people with Addison's disease (primary adrenal insufficiency), especially when their hormone replacement therapy is inadequate or missed or during periods of extreme stress (e.g., illness, trauma, or surgery).

Management: IV Hydrocortisone

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Type 1.5 Diabetes Mellitus is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Characterized by autoimmune destruction of beta cells

options.label: B
options.text: Patients are typically diagnosed in childhood

options.label: C
options.text: It is often misdiagnosed as Type 2 DM

options.label: D
options.text: C-peptide levels decline more slowly compared to Type 1 DM

questions.correct_answer: B. Patients are typically diagnosed in childhood

questions.text: Which part of the kidney is affected in Gordon syndrome?

options.label: C
options.text: Ascending limb of the loop of Henle

options.label: D
options.text: Descending limb of the loop of Henle

questions.explanation:
Inheritance

Autosomal dominant (mostly)

Pathogenesis

Mutations in the WNK1, WNK4, CUL3, or KLHL3 genes result in abnormalities in serine/threonine kinases that dysregulate the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC) in the distal nephron (Option A). This leads to increased sodium and chloride reabsorption, causing extracellular volume expansion and subsequent hypertension.

Clinical Presentation

Non-specific symptoms like muscle weakness, fatigue, hypertension (not always)

Laboratory Findings
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis
  • Hypercalciuria
  • Low or low-normal plasma renin activity
  • Low serum aldosterone levels (relative to hyperkalemia)
  • Normal kidney function/normal glomerular filtration

Management
  • Correction of electrolyte abnormalities
  • Salt restriction
  • Thiazide diuretics

questions.text: All of the following are clinical manifestations of Liddle’s syndrome except?
questions.explanation:
Definition

An autosomal dominant genetic disorder characterized by hypertension with hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis, hyporeninemia, and suppressed aldosterone secretion

Pathophysiology

Mutations in SCNN1A, SCNN1B, and SCNN1G genes → α, β, and γ subunits of ENaC (Epithelial Sodium Channel) altered → Increased Epithelial Sodium Channel activity→Elevated sodium reabsorption in the distal nephron → Sodium retention

Clinical features

- Early-onset hypertension (as early as 2 years of age) (Option C ruled out)

- Hypokalemia (Option A ruled out) and metabolic alkalosis

- Suppressed plasma renin (Option B ruled out) and aldosterone levels (Option D)

- Fatigue, muscle weakness, dizziness, and vision changes

Management

- Potassium-sparing diuretics: Amiloride or Triamterene

- Salt restriction
